entry.title: Set Theory
entry.content:
Set

notations

  • relashionship of set
    • \(A\subseteq B\iff orall x(x\in A ox\in B)\)
    • \(A=B\iff orall x(x\in A\leftrightarrowx\in B)\)
  • operations of set
    • \(A\cap B=\{ x|x\in A \wedge x\inB\}\)
    • \(A\cup B=\{ x|x\in A \vee x\inB\}\)
    • \(A\setminus B=\{x|x\in A\wedge x otinB\}\)
    • \(A^c=\{x|x otin A\}\)
    • \(A\Delta B=(A\cup B)\setminus(A\capB)\)
    • \( igcap_{i\in I}A_i=\{x| orall i\inI,x\in A_i\}\)
    • \( igcup_{i\in I}A_i=\{x|\exists i\inI,x\in A_i\}\)

limit of set

a sequence of set \(\{A_n\}_{n=1}^\infty\) if \(A_n\subset A_{n+1}\), we says it ismonotone increasing and denote \( igcup_{n=1}^\infty A_n\) as \(\lim_{n o\infty}A_n\) if \(A_n\supset A_{n+1}\), we says it ismonotone decreasing and denote \( igcap_{n=1}^\infty A_n\) as \(\lim_{n o\infty}A_n\)

\(\{ igcap_{k=n}^\inftyA_k\}_{n=1}^\infty\) is monotone increasing \[\lim\inf_{n o\infty}A_n= igcup_{n=1}^\infty igcap_{k=n}^\infty A_k\] \(x\in\lim\inf_{n o\infty}A_n\iff\exists n, orallk\geq n,(x\in A_k)\) \(\{ igcap_{k=n}^\infty A_k\}_{n=1}^\infty\)is monotone decreasing \[\lim\sup_{n o\infty}A_n= igcap_{n=1}^\infty igcup_{k=n}^\infty A_k\] \(x\in\lim\sup_{n o\infty}A_n\iff orall n,\existsk\geq n,(x\in A_k)\)

n-tuple: \[(x_1,x_2,\cdots,x_n)=\{x_1,\{x_1,x_2\},\{x_1,x_2,x_3\},\cdots\}\]Cartesian product \[A imesB=\{(a,b)|a\in A \wedge b\in B\}\] specifically, \(A^4=A imes A imes A imes A\)

Power set the power set of \(S\), denoted as \(\mathscr{P}(S)\), such that \[X\in\mathscr{P}(S)\iff X\subseteq S\]

Partition \(\mathscr{A}\) is a partition of nonemptyset \(X\) if - \( orall A\in\mathscr{A},(A eq\emptyset)\)- \( igcup_{A\in\mathscr{A}}A=X\) -\( orall A_1,A_2\in X,(A\capB eq\emptyset o A_1=A_2)\) ## mapping \(f\) is a mapping from \(X\) to \(Y\), denoted as \(f:X o Y\),if - \( orall x\in X,\exists y\in Y,\Big((x,y)\inf\Big)\) - \( orall x\in X, orally_1,y_2\in Y,\Big((x,y_1)\in f\wedge(x,y_2)\in f oy_1=y_2\Big)\)

\(f\) is a correspondence rulebetween two nonempty set \(X,Y\) andeach \(x\in X\) map to a unique \(y\in Y\), then \(f\) is a mapping from \(X\) to \(Y\) denoted as \(f:X o Y\) - domain: \(D=X\) - codomain: \(Y\) - range: \(R=\{y|y=f(x),x\in D\}\) - If \(x\) is an element of \(X\), and \(f(x)=y\), then \(x\) is preimage of \(y\), \(y\)is image of \(x\),denoted as \(x\mapsto y\)

bijection & injection & surjection -injection/one to one: \( orall x_1,x_2\inX,(f(x_1)=f(x_2) o x_1=x_2)\) - surjection/onto: \( orall y\in Y,\exists x \in X,(f(x)=y)\) -bijection: \( orall x_1,x_2\inX,(f(x_1)=f(x_2) o x_1=x_2)\wedge orall y\in Y,\exists x \inX,(f(x)=y)\)

  • function
    • a mapping from number set to number set
  • functional
    • a mapping from function set to number set
  • operator
    • a mapping from function set to function set
  • identity function
    • \(i_X:X o X\) defined by \(i_X(x)=x\)
  • composition
    • \(f:A o B,g:B o C\), then \(g\circ f(x)=g(f(x))\)
    • \(h\circ (g\circ f)=(h\circ g)\circf\)
  • inverse
    • let \(f:X o Y\) a bijection, \(f(x)=y\iff f^{-1}(y)=x\)
    • \(f^{-1}\circ f=i_X\) and \(f\circ f^{-1}=i_Y\)
    • \((f\circ g)^{-1}=g^{-1}\circf^{-1}\)
  • image of \(A\subseteqX\)
    • \(f(A)=\{f(x)|x\in A\}\)
  • inverse images of \(B\subseteq Y\)
    • \(f^{-1}(B)=\{y|f(y)\in B\}\)
  • transformation \(f:X oX\)
    • permutation \(T\)is a transformation and a bijetion
    • identity map \(I:X oX, orall x\in X,(I(x)=x)\)

indicator function suppose \(S\subseteq X\), then \(\chi_S:X o\{0,1\}\) defined by \(\chi_S(x)=0\) if \(x otin S\), and \(\chi_S(x)=1\) if \(x\in S\)

Relation

if \(R\subseteq X^n\), it is calledn-ary relation more often, we discuss binaryrelation

suppose \(R\) is a binary relationon \(X\), it has the followingproperties conditionally - reflexive property - \( orall x\in X((x,x)\in R)\) -symetric property - \((x_1,x_2)\in R o(x_2,x_1)\in R\) -antisymetric property - \((x_1,x_2)\in R\wedge (x_2,x_1)\in R ox_1=x_2\) - strongly antisymetric property -\((x_1,x_2)\in R o(x_2,x_1) ot\in R\)- transitive property - \((x_1,x_2\in R\wedge(x_2,x_3)\in R o(x_1,x_3)\inR)\) - EXAMPLE1:"greater than" relation on the set of realnumbers is transitive - 传递闭包(transitive closure) -The transitive closure of \(R\),denoted by \(R^*\),is defined as \(R^*=R igcup\{(x_i,x_j)|\exists x_{k_1}\cdotsx_{k_t}((x_i,x_{k_1}),(x_{k_1},x_{k_2}),\cdots,(x_{k_t},x_j)\inR)\}\) - 其实\(R^*\)就是包含\(R\)的具有传递性的最小集合 -Warshall Algorithm 寻找传递闭包的算法 -n次循环{找到(a,i)(i,b),add \(A imesB\)}

\(R\) is an equivalence relation ifand only if it is: - reflexive - symetric - transitive when \(R\) is an equivalence relation set, wewrite \((x,y)\in R\) as \(x\sim y\), we also define \(E_x=\{y\in X:x\sim y\}\), calledequivalence class

order

preorder

for a given \((X,R)\), \(X\) is a ==preordered set==, a.k.a.quasi-order set, when \(R\) is: -irreflexive ? reflexive - transitive

partial order

for a given \((X,R)\), \(X\) is a ==partially ordered set==, when\(R\) is: - reflexive - antisymetric -transitive

we write \((x,y)\in R\) as \(x\preceq y\), called \(x\) precede \(y\) if \(x\preceqy \wedge x eq y\), they we write it as \(x\prec y\), called \(x\) strictly precede \(y\)

comparability suppose \(x_1,x_2\inX\) and \(X\) is a partiallyordered set, then if \(x_1\preceq x_2\veex_2\preceq x_1\), we says they are comparable, otherwice, theyare uncomparable and written as \(x_1||x_2\) trichotomy of relations: \[x_1\preceq x_2\vee x_2\preceq x_1\veex_1||x_2\]

given a partial order set \((X,\preceq)\) and a set \(S\subseteq X\) - lower bound &upper bound: - if \(\exists m\inX, orall x\in S,(m\preceq x)\), then \(m\) is a lower bound of \(S\) - infimum &supremum: - if \(l\) is alower bound of \(S\), and \( orall m,(m\preceq l)\), then \(l\) is an infimum of \(S\) - \(l\) is denoted as \(\inf S\) - minimal &maximal: - if \(\exists m\inS, orall x\in S,(m preceq x)\) , then \(m\) is a minimal of \(S\) - minimum &maximum: - if \(\exists m\inS, orall x\in S,(m\preceq x)\) then \(m\) is a minimum of \(S\)

Hasse diagram we say \(x\)is a immediate predcessor of \(y\) ifand only if \[(x\prec y)\wedge( eg\existsz\in X,(x\prec z\wedge z\prec y))\] we denote it as \(x\ll y\)

then, we draw a line between two elements if and only if one is animmediate predcessor of the other, this is called Hasse diagram![[Pasted image 20231108153940.png|250]]

totally ordered set

a partially ordered set \(X\) is a==totally ordered set==, a.k.a. chain or linear order, when: \[ orall x,y\in X,(x\preceq y\vee y\preceq x\veex=y)\] \(A\) is a ==well-orderedset==, when: \[ orall S\subsetX,S eq\emptyset, ig(\exists x\in S, orall y\in S,(x=y\veexRy) ig)\]

lattice

two equivalent definitions of lattice \(\vee,\wedge:L^2 o L\) are both operator on\(L\) \((L,\vee,\wedge)\) is a lattice, if and onlyif the both operators suffices: - commutitive law - associative law -absorption law: \(x\wedge(x\veey)=x\)

we can deduce idempotent law then: \(x\wedge x=x\)

principle of duality?

\((L,\preceq)\) is a lattice, if andonly if each two elements have a supremum and a infremum suppose \(x\wedge y=x o x\preceq y\), then \((L,\preceq)\) is partially ordered

\(x\wedge y=\inf(x,y)\) \(x\vee y=\sup(x,y)\)

a lattice have a lower bound \(0\)and an upper bound \(I\)

distributive lattice a distributive lattice satisfies: -distributive law: \(x\wedge (y\vee z)=(x\wedgey)\vee(x\wedge z)\)

a totally ordered set is a lattice

join irreducible elements \(x\) is a join irreducible element(既约并元)if and only of \(x=0\) or \((x=y_1\vee y_2) o (a=x)\vee (a=y)\) \(x\) is called an atom if and only if itimmediately succeed \(0\) \(x=d_1\vee d_2\vee\cdots\vee d_n\)

complement \(y\) is calledthe complement of \(x\) if: - \(x\vee y=I\) - \(x\wedge y=0\) complement is unique ifexists

a lattice is complemented if all elements in it has a complement

some examples of lattice - \((\mathbb{Z}^+,\mid)\) or \((\mathbb{Z}^+,\gcd,\mathrm{lcm})\) - \((\mathcal{P}(S),\subseteq)\) or \((\mathcal{P}(S),\cup,\cap)\)

Order isomorphic

we says \(X_1\) is order isomorphicto \(X_2\) , written as \(X_1\cong X_2\), if there exists a bijection\(f:X_1 o X_2\) satisfies:\[x\preceq y o f(x)\preceq f(y)\wedge x||y of(x)||f(y)\]

Cardinal

the Cardinality of set \(A\), denoted as \(|A|\) we says \(A\) and \(B\) are equivalent (or equinumerous) if andonly if there exists a bijection \(f:A oB\) - \(f_{bi}:A o B\iff \lvertA vert=\lvert B vert\) - \(f_{in}:A o B\iff\lvert A vert\leq\lvertB vert\) - \(f_{sur}:A o B\iff\lvertA vert\geq\lvert B vert\)

\(A\) is a finiteset if and only if \(\existsn\in\mathbb{N},(|\{1,2,\cdots,n\}|=|A|)\) otherwise, it is is ainfinite set

\(A\) is a countableset if and only if \(\existsS\subseteq\mathbb{N},(|S|=|A|)\) otherwise, \(A\) is a uncountableset

Cantor-Bernstein Theorem(康托-伯恩斯坦定理) \[\lvert A vert\leq\lvert B vert\wedge\lvertB vert\leq\lvert A vert\iff\lvert A vert=\lvert B vert\]Proof: use Banach Theorem: suppose \(f:A o B,g:B o A\), \(\existsA_0,A_1,B_0,B_1(B_1=\{f(x)|x\in A_0\}\wedge A_1=\{g(x)|x\inB_0\}\) let \(f,g\) are bothinjection, we have\(f_{bi}:A_0 o B_1g_{bi}:B_0 o A_1\)

entry.content:
Real number theory

density \( orallx_1,x_2\in\mathbb{R},\existsx\in\mathbb{R},(x_1<x<x_2)\)

the completeness axiom of the reals - every nonemptysubset of real numbers that is bounded above has a supremum - any Cauchysequence converges

Limit

Definition of Limits

Limits of Sequences

Set an infinite sequence \(\{x_n\}\), if: \[\exists L, orall\epsilon>0,\existsN\in\mathbb{N}, orall n,(n>N o\lvert x_n-L vert<\epsilon) ag1\] we say that it converge to \(L\), which is denoted as \(\lim_{n o\infty}x_n=L\)

\[ orall G>0,\exists N\in\mathbb{N}, orall n,(n>N o x_n>G) ag2\] we say that itis disvergent, which is denoted as \(\lim_{n o\infty}x_n=\infty\)

Limits of Functions

Set a function \(f(x)\), suppose\(\mathring{U}(x_0)\subseteq D_f\), if:\[\existsL, orall\epsilon>0,\exists\delta>0 , orall x,(\lvert x-x_0 vert<\delta o \lvert f(x)-L vert<\epsilon) ag1\] wesay that it converge to \(L\), which isdenoted as \(\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=L\)

\[\exists L, orall\epsilon>0,\existsG\in R , orall x,(x>G o \lvert f(x)-L vert<\epsilon) ag2\] we say that it converge to \(L\), which is denoted as \(\lim_{x o\infty}f(x)=L\)

\[ orall K>0,\exists\delta>0, orall x,(\lvert x-x_0 vert<\delta o f(x)>K) ag3\] wesay that it is disvergent, which is denoted as \(\lim_{x o x_0}f(x)=\infty\)

\[ orall K>0,\exists G>0, orallx,(x>G o f(x)>K) ag4\] we say that it is disvergent,which is denoted as \(\lim_{x o\infty}f(x)=\infty\)

One-sided Limits

left-sided limit: \(\lim_{x ox_0^+}f(x)\) right-sided limit: \(\lim_{x o x_0^-}f(x)\)

Applying Limits

Properties of Limits

  • uniqueness of limit(唯一性) \((\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=L_1)\wedge(\lim_{x o x_0}f(x)=L_2) o (L_1=L_2)\)
  • boundedness of limit(有界性) \((\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=L) o(\exists M, orall x\in\mathring{U}(x_0,\delta),(M\geqx))\)
  • locally sign-preserving property(保号性) \((\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=L)\wedge(L<t) o(\exists\delta>0, orallx\in\mathring{U}(x_0,\delta),(x<t))\)
  • squeeze theorem(迫敛性) if \((\lim_{x ox_0}g(x)=\lim_{x o x_0}h(x)=L)\) and \( orall x\in\mathring{U}(x_0),(g(x)\leq f(x)\leqh(x))\), then \(\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=L\)

subsequence: \(\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=L \leftrightarrow orall \{x_{n_k}\}(\lim_{k o\infty}x_{n_k}=L)\)

Criteria for the Existenceof Limits

Squeeze Theorem: \[g_1(x)\leq f(x) \leq g_2(x)\wedge\lim _{x ox_0}g_1(x)=\lim _{x o x_0}g_2(x)=L o\lim _{x o x_0}f(x)=L\]an important limit: \(\lim _{x o0}\cfrac{\sin x}{x}=1\) proof: \(x\in(0, rac\pi2) o\sin x<x< an x o\cosx<\cfrac{\sin x}{x}<1\)

Monotone Convergence Theorem: If a function orsequence of real numbers is monotonic and bounded, then it definitelyhas a limit an important limit: \(\lim _{x o\infty}(1+\cfrac 1x)^x=e\) proof:

Cauchy审敛定理:两个足够大号码的点之差小于任意给定的正数\(\epsilon\) 海涅定理 ### Infinitesimal ####Infinitesimals if ==\(\lim\alpha(x)=0\)==, then we call \(\alpha(x)\) is the infinitesimal quantityin this limit process

a theorem that relate limits and infinitesimal quantities: \[\lim f(x)=L\ifff(x)+\alpha(x)=L,\lim\alpha(x)=0\]

properties of infinitesimal: \(\limC\cdot\alpha=0\) based on infinitesimals, we can deduce thefour arithmetic rules of limits

Order of infinitesimals

sometimes the four arithmetic rules of limits fail, we call theselimits indeterminate: examples: \(\cfrac00,\cfrac\infty\infty,0\cdot\infty,\infty-\infty,\infty^0,0^0,(1+0)^\infty\)Fortunately, all above can be reduced to the the form of \(\cfrac 00\)

  • Higher-order infinitesimal: \(\lim\cfrac eta\alpha=0\) , denoted as==\( eta=o(\alpha)\)==
  • Lower-order infinitesimal: \(\lim \cfrac eta \alpha=\infty\) , denoted as ==\(\alpha=o( eta)\)==
  • Same-order infinitesimals: \(\lim \cfrac eta \alpha=c\) , denoted as ==\( eta\sim c\alpha\)==
  • \(k\)th-order infinitesimal: \(\lim \cfrac eta {\alpha^k}=c\) , denotedas ==\( eta\sim c\alpha^k\)==
  • Equivalent infinitesimal: \(\lim \cfrac eta \alpha=1\) , denoted as==\( eta\sim\alpha\)==

Among all, Equivalent infinitesimal is the most important one, forthe reason that we use them to simplify equations very often, which isbased on the ==equivalent infinitesimal substitution theorems==: If\(\alpha\sim eta\) , then \(\lim \alpha f(x)=\lim eta f(x)\)

after we determine a Reference infinitesimal, often\(x\), we look for \(k\) such that \(f(x)=cx^k+o(x^k)\), then \(cx^k\) is called Infinitesimalprincipal

Useful EquivalentInfinitesimal

when \(x o0\): - \(x\sim\sin x\sim an x\) - \(\cos x\sim 1- rac12x^2\) - \(x\sim e^x-1\sim\ln (x+1)\) - \((1+x)^\mu-1\sim\mu x\)

hint: don't forget when \(u(x) o0\), all \(x\) above can bereplaced with \(u(x)\) integrally ###Continuity #### Definition of Continuity Continuity at onepoint set a function \(f(x)\),suppose \(\mathring{U}(x_0)\subseteqD_f\), if limit below exists: \[\lim_{x o x_0}f(x)=f(x_0)\] then we said\(f(x)\) is continuous at \(x_0\)

one-sided continuity: - left-sided continuity: \(\lim_{x o x_0^+}f(x)= f(x_0)\) -right-sided continuity: \(\lim_{x ox_0^-}f(x)= f(x_0)\)

Continuity on an interval If \( orall x_0\in (a,b),(\lim_{x ox_0}f(x)=f(x_0))\) and \(\lim_{x oa^+}f(x)= f(a)\) , we say that \(f(x)\) is continuious on \([a,b)\) , denoted as \(f(x)\in C[a,b)\) distinction between openinterval & closed interval

Discontinuity - Removable Discontinuity: \(\lim_{x o x_0}f(x)=L\) but \(L eq x_0\) - Jump Discontinuity: \(\lim_{x o x_0^+}f(x) eq\lim_{x ox_0^-}f(x)\) - Infinite Discontinuity: \(\lim_{x o x_0}f(x)=\infty\) - OscillatoryDiscontinuity: \(\lim_{x o0}\sin rac1x\)

uniform continuity

Properties of continuousfunction

  • continuous functions remain continuous after basic arithmeticoperations, composite operations, and inverse operations

  • elementary functions are all continuous

  • continuous function on a closed interval

    • has both minimum and maximum
    • intermediate value thm \[f(x)\inC[a,b] o orall c\in(f(a),f(b)),\exists\xi\in(a,b),(c=f(\xi))\]

Derivative & Differential

Derivative

Definition of Derivative

set a function \(f(x)\), suppose\(\mathring{U}(x_0)\subseteq D_f\), thederivative of \(f(x)\) at \(x_0\) is defined as: \[f'(x_0)=\lim _{\Delta x o 0}\cfrac{f(x_0+\Delta x)-f(x_0)}{\Delta x}\] if the limit exists, we saythat \(f(x)\) is derivable at \(x_0\)

derivative function of \(f(x)\) is denoted as \(f'(x)\) and it is a function such that:\[ orall x\in D_f,(f'(x)=\lim _{\Deltax o 0}\cfrac {f(x_0+\Delta x)-f(x_0)}{\Delta x})\]

one-sided derivative - right-sided derivative: \(f'_+(x)\) - left-sided derivative:\(f'_-(x)\)

Derivability

\(f\) is continuous \(\Rightarrow\) \(f\) is derivable continue but notderivable: \(f\) is continuous but thederivative limit does not exist - cusp: \(f'_+(x) eq f'_-(x)\) - vertical:\(f'(x)=\infty\)

derivative of a derivable function is continue orhas oscillatory discontinuity

Derivation

Derivation
